linkTarget.anchoringText: In figure 1 you may know the performance of Guantao and Xing VI reservoirs in single well steam injection operation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Curve of Guantao reservoir & Xing VI reservoir in various production periods

formatted-caption.caption-text: Curve of Guantao reservoir & Xing VI reservoir in various production periods

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 2 and Figure 3 we can know that the upper interval is better developed than the lower interval which is hard to be affected by steam.
From Figure 2 and Figure 3 we can know that the upper interval is better developed than the lower interval which is hard to be affected by steam.

Based on numeric simulation we can see that oil saturation at the bottom is about 35% while the oil saturation in sections between wells is as high as 50%-65% (Figure 4 and Figure 5) in the last cycles (7-8 cycles) of steam injection for Guantao and Xing VI.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Remaining oil saturation distribution after 8 cycles of steam injection for Xing VI (plan)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Remaining oil saturation distribution after 8 cycles of steam injection for Xing VI (plan)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on numeric simulation we can see that oil saturation at the bottom is about 35% while the oil saturation in sections between wells is as high as 50%-65% (Figure 4 and Figure 5) in the last cycles (7-8 cycles) of steam injection for Guantao and Xing VI.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Remaining oil saturation distribution after 7 cycles of steam injection for Guantao (plan)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Remaining oil saturation distribution after 7 cycles of steam injection for Guantao (plan)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Observation well 1 that is 13 meters off 36-7046 well and observation well 2 that is 23 meters away from 36-7046 well were drilled to gauge temperature (Figure 6). Temperature changes are shown in Table 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Distribution of A group, CH block

formatted-caption.caption-text: Distribution of A group, CH block

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 7 we can see that there are 2 peaks in temperature after the implementation of multi-well stimulation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Temperature changes of Group A in CH block

formatted-caption.caption-text: Temperature changes of Group A in CH block

linkTarget.anchoringText: It is estimated that steam may be injected for 13 times in the multi-well stimulation pattern, while the average single well production is 15353t (recovery rate 24.4%). However, the conventional single well steam stimulation may only last for 10 cycles of steam injection, the average single well production is 11604t (recovery rate 18.5%). Therefore, the multi-well stimulation technology increases 3 more steam injection cycles and improves the recovery rate by 6% (Figure 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Oil output in the multi-well stimulation pattern for Group A, CH block

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil output in the multi-well stimulation pattern for Group A, CH block

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 9 we can see that CO2 has the best role in reducing the oil viscosity, while natural gas and nitrogen follow it. All of them may be dissolved in tight oil, reduce its viscosity and expands its volume. CO2 is selected as the EOR gas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Relationship between GOR & viscosity & mixing pressure of tight oil

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relationship between GOR & viscosity & mixing pressure of tight oil

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: 3-dimension graph of a single well module

formatted-caption.caption-text: 3-dimension graph of a single well module

linkTarget.anchoringText: A horizontal well is established in the module. It is 1335.5m deep, its KOP is at the depth of 990m, its horizontal interval is 200m long. Initial reservoir pressure is 13MPa and the perforated interval is in the 3rd layer, as shown in Figure 11.

From Figure 12 we can know that temperature of liquefied CO2 varies a lot with different injection speeds, in that the heat diffusion time is different. The faster CO2 is injected, the shorter the heat diffusion time is, which makes downhole temperature change less. Besides, liquefied CO2 becomes hotter and hotter from KOP (at the depth of 990m) due to the lack of thermal isolation pipes (Figure 13). It is proved that the thermal isolation pipe plays an important role in heat isolation on vertical segments, making the casing temperature close to the initial formation temperature and stabilizing casing as well as cement sheath.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Borehole temperature change with various CO2 injection speeds (injected for 20 consecutive hours)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Borehole temperature change with various CO2 injection speeds (injected for 20 consecutive hours)

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 12 we can know that temperature of liquefied CO2 varies a lot with different injection speeds, in that the heat diffusion time is different. The faster CO2 is injected, the shorter the heat diffusion time is, which makes downhole temperature change less. Besides, liquefied CO2 becomes hotter and hotter from KOP (at the depth of 990m) due to the lack of thermal isolation pipes (Figure 13). It is proved that the thermal isolation pipe plays an important role in heat isolation on vertical segments, making the casing temperature close to the initial formation temperature and stabilizing casing as well as cement sheath.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: mechanical module of the vacuum heat isolation pipe

formatted-caption.caption-text: mechanical module of the vacuum heat isolation pipe

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 14 we can see that CO2 does not dissolve by high rates in heavy oil, while its dissolution is much lower than that in light oil, in that gum and bitumen affects CO2's dissolubility. CO2's dissolubility declines as temperature goes up and improves as pressure increases, which is due to CO2 molecular motion and molecular gaps. In low pressure condition molecular gaps of crude oil are relatively large and CO2 molecular motion affects the dissolubility. As temperature goes up, CO2 molecules move faster and thus hardly dissolve in tight oil.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Relationship between CO2's solubility and saturation pressure in various temperatures

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relationship between CO2's solubility and saturation pressure in various temperatures

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 15 we can see that the gel system hydrates faster and faster as temperature goes up, stabilizing for a long period of time at 200°C. From Figure 16 we can see that tight oil does not affect the gel system's hydration a lot.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Relationship between the gel hydration period and temperature

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relationship between the gel hydration period and temperature

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 15 we can see that the gel system hydrates faster and faster as temperature goes up, stabilizing for a long period of time at 200°C. From Figure 16 we can see that tight oil does not affect the gel system's hydration a lot.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16

linkTarget.anchoringText: A diverter is run into the role via the tool described in Figure 17, while the diverter's slip stretches to the casing wall to anchor itself after a ball is thrown to build up inner pressure. Then drill tools are rotated until they are retrieved. The diverter is fixed at its designated position and necessary downhole tools are run into the borehole.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Schematic diagram of a slip-type diverter

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic diagram of a slip-type diverter

linkTarget.anchoringText: There are mainly 3 types of milling cones, they single milling cones, double milling cones and compound milling cones (Figure 18).
